keyTakeAways: Six universities have formally rejected a White House funding compact that ties federal grants and privileges to ideological policy changes.

The proposed compact includes demands such as removing sex and ethnicity from admissions, capping international enrollment at 15%, enforcing gender definitions based on reproductive function, and conducting annual anonymous polls on compliance.
The White House frames the compact as a way to promote a 'vibrant marketplace of ideas' and improve higher education, but universities argue it undermines academic freedom and institutional autonomy.
Notable rejections include MIT, Penn, Brown University, USC, Dartmouth College, and the University of Virginia, all citing concerns over academic freedom and governance independence.
The University of Texas at Austin is the only university mentioned that has not rejected the offer, expressing openness to dialogue rather than firm commitment.
Other schools such as Vanderbilt University and the University of Arizona are reviewing the proposal and have not committed to joining.
The compact was drafted in December 2024 with collaborative edits since the president returned to office, indicating evolving policy direction.
Schools have responded with strong emphasis on maintaining institutional sovereignty and free inquiry, especially in the face of potential federal overreach.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Six U.S. universities — including MIT, Penn, Brown University, USC, Dartmouth College, and the University of Virginia — have rejected a White House proposal offering expanded federal funding in exchange for agreeing to ideological policy changes. The compact demands that universities remove sex and ethnicity from admissions, cap international enrollment at 15%, define gender based on biological processes, and conduct annual anonymous compliance polls. The schools argue that such demands threaten academic freedom and institutional autonomy, emphasizing that federal funding should be awarded based on merit, not ideological alignment. While the White House sees the initiative as a way to improve higher education through ideological standardization, universities view it as an overreach of federal power and a potential threat to academic independence. The proposal, initially sent to nine institutions on October 1, 2025, has since expanded to include three additional schools, with a deadline of November 21, 2025, for initial signatories. The University of Texas at Austin has not rejected the offer, instead expressing openness to dialogue, while Vanderbilt and the University of Arizona are currently reviewing the proposal. California Governor Gavin Newsom has also signaled political resistance by threatening to withhold state funding from institutions that accept the compact, further intensifying the debate over federal and state influence in higher education.
title: Six Universities Reject White House Funding Deal with Attached Demands
